question.body: Lymph tissue, and particularly the organs of the lymphoid system, seem to be organized in a way that builds from loose tissue to highly organized structures. Lymph nodes and the spleen both are encapsulated and are more highly organized, but there are two significant differences between them. What are they?

multiple_choice.choice: The spleen has red and white pulp and is fed only by the lymph vessels.
Because lymph nodes have one-way lymph flow they cannot filter the fluid, so they do not have an immune function.
The lymph node has white cells while the spleen has red and white pulp; and the lymph node filters lymph while the spleen filters blood.
The lymph node and spleen have contrasting immune functions, and only the spleen filters lymph.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Lymph nodes receive lymph and the spleen receives blood.
Incorrect. Lymph nodes have both immune and filtering function.
Correct. Both organs provide immune and filtering functions, but one filters lymph and the other filters blood.
Incorrect. The spleen filters blood, not lymph.
